Join Gloria Groom, chair and David and Mary Winton Green Curator of European Painting and Sculpture, and art historian Richard Brettell, University of Texas at Dallas, for an engaging conversation around their work and research on Impressionist paintings. Brettell, one of the world's preeminent authorities on Impressionism and French Painting, will also discuss ideas drawn from his recent publication, On Modern Beauty: Three Paintings by Manet, Gauguin, and Cézanne. This program is presented in anticipation of the exhibition Monet and Chicago.

Richard Brettell
Richard Brettell is among the foremost authorities in the world on Impressionism and French Painting of the period 1830–1930. He received his BA, MA, and PhD from Yale University, and has taught at the University of Texas, Northwestern University, the University of Chicago, Yale University, and Harvard University, and is currently Margaret M. McDermott Distinguished Chair of Art and Aesthetic Studies and the Edith O'Donnell Distinguished Chair at the University of Texas at Dallas. He is also an international museum consultant with projects in Europe, Asia, and the United States.  

In 1980, Dr. Brettell was appointed Searle Curator of European Painting at the Art Institute of Chicago. In 1988, he became the McDermott Director of the Dallas Museum of Art (DMA). Since leaving the DMA, Dr. Brettell has been involved with the purchase of the M. H.W. Ritchie Collection for the Dixon Gallery and Gardens in Memphis, the building and renovation program of the Portland Museum of Art, and the Millennium Gift of the Sara Lee Collection, for which the company won the National Medal for the Arts in 1999. He is senior advisor for international art for the National Gallery of Australia and is working with Professor Stephen Eisenman of Northwestern University to catalogue the Norton Simon Museum’s collection of 19th and 20th-century French paintings.

Dr. Brettell worked with Elizabeth and Felix Rohatyn, former ambassador to France, and Francoise Cachin, former director of the French National Museums, to create FRAME (French/Regional/American Museum Exchange), a coalition of 24 regional museums in France and America. Dr. Brettell established the American office of FRAME at UT Dallas.

Dr. Brettell is actively engaged with architecture in Dallas. He is the founding president and a board member of the Dallas Architecture Forum and a consultant to Philip Johnson for the Cathedral of Hope in Dallas. He also curated an exhibition devoted to modern architecture for UT Dallas in January/February 2002.
